awd_titl_txt: DMREF: Collaborative Research: Self-assembled peptide-pi-electron supramolecular polymers for bioinspired energy harvesting, transport and management
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical Description: Nature exquisitely controls the spatial arrangement of key pigments and dyes in the process of photosynthesis to harness solar energy.  Mimicry of controlled dye arrangements in synthetic materials can be realized through tailored design of molecules and molecular arrangements. However, exerting reliable control over the assembly of engineered molecular materials in the crucial 10-100 nanometer "mesoscale" regime, thousands of times smaller than a millimeter, remains elusive. Such mesoscale molecular structures will combine charge and energy transfer activities with capabilities for assembly in biological solutions, and compatibility with biological environments. Given the multitude of molecular design possibilities, it is essential that experimental programs incorporate computer modeling and data-driven screening to guide experimental design and synthesis. Tight integration and mutually reinforcing feedback between computation and experiment can reveal fundamental design rules for molecular assembly, and accelerate the discovery and development of multi-molecule assemblies with tailored structure and function. This project will develop these functional molecular superstructures in a collaboration encompassing molecular synthesis, self-assembly analogous to biological systems, modeling of the structures and electrical properties of the assemblies, and utilizing the assemblies to manage interactions between light and electricity. The PIs are committed to workforce training and development within this project, guiding the next generation of materials and data scientists of diverse socio-economic background in state-of-the-art tools and exposing them to an integrated interdisciplinary mode of work that will define future research. 

Technical Description: The photophysical and electrical properties of pi-conjugated supramolecular systems depend critically on the explicit nature of the intermolecular electronic interactions. These interactions are governed by the precise molecular structure and chemistry and emergent supramolecular arrangements. The PIs developed a peptide construct that offer a pathway to exert such control over emergent supramolecular structure through tailoring of steric bulk and variable hydrophobicity of the component sequences to influence intermolecular orientations, higher-order fibrilization, and specific electronic outcomes. They initially used an Edisonian approach to uncover these variations, but the goals of this project are to wield explicit engineered control through tightly integrated atomistic simulations and electronic structure calculations. The research activities build upon the team's strong foundation to accomplish these goals in two specific objectives: (i) the development of sophisticated peptidic semiconductor materials with advanced optoelectronic functionality and (ii) the development of new assembly paradigms leading to heterogeneous peptidic nanomaterials with chemical and electronic gradients and localized electric fields.  The execution of this work will entail interconnected efforts by the research team in the (i) synthesis of new pi-electron units and new self-assembling peptides, (ii) molecular and data-driven modeling of the nanomaterial aggregates and their higher-order assemblies, and (iii) characterization of electrical transport within the nanomaterials. This project will make special provision for research opportunities for undergraduate students, women, and underrepresented minorities. The PIs will train and mentor researchers in state-of-the-art experimental and computational tools and expose them to an integrated interdisciplinary mode of work. K-12 outreach activities will inspire excitement and awareness of materials science and encourage students to pursue higher education in science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) fields.

por.por_cntn:
INTELLECTUAL MERIT: We established robust structure-activity relationships to correlate the pi-peptide molecular structure with the resulting nanostructural or electronic properties. This entailed two-way interactions where intuitive empirical material design informed on initial computational targets and where computational screening identified targets that would have been indiscernable from chemical intuition alone. The foundational experimental elements along with the state-of-the-art in the field were reviewed in two articles prepared during the award period. Diversification of the peptide and pi-core segments: We elaborated upon the pi-core structures to understand how torsional strain in oligothiophenes impacts the exciton coupling and how the length of the thiophene oligomers comprising the pi-core impacts the assembly and the phase behavior. We expanded the pi-core choice to privileged semiconductor structures such as benzodithiophenes and diketopyrrolo pyrroles. We explored the structural and electronic effects of decoupling the peptide and pi segments by way of electronically inert alkyl spacers, where we found unexpectedly that the length of this spacer had a direct impact on the chiroptical nature of the intermolecular pi-core association. Approaches to complex nanostructures: We prepared halogenated pi-peptides with elemental tags to distinguish subunits within heterostructures via cutting-edge spectroscopies. We also examined how the spatial placement of different flavors of hydrophobicity within otherwise constitutionally isomeric pi-peptides impacted nanostructure electronics and morphology. Extensions to hybrid organic-inorganic conductive nanomaterials: We discovered unexpectedly that certain assembly conditions led to a mineralization process as templated by the peptidic nanomaterials. Specifically, KCl-coated nanomaterials showed unusually high conductivities approaching those of metals. This is related conceptually to our studies of pi-conjugated materials with pendant ionizable carboxylic acid groups, which play an additional role here to mineralize the KCl crystals. Classical and classical/quantum multi-scale modeling. (I) Molecular simulations predicted charged pi-peptides should show limited aggregation into dimers and trimers driven by strong hydrophobic driving forces. This result was subsequently validated by fluorescence correlation spectroscopy and established a new paradigm for pH-triggered assembly. (II) Molecular dynamics simulations revealed that smaller amino acids promoted linear stacking within pi-peptide dimers and subsequent density functional theory calculations showed linear stacking to promote electronic delocalization improved charge transport.Coarse grained molecular models. Bottom-up implicit solvent155 and top-down ultra-coarse grained models enabled simulation of pi-peptide assembly over length and time scales far beyond all-atom calculations. Ultra-coarse grained simulation of ten thousand pi-peptides over hundreds of nanometers and hundreds of microseconds revealed desirable regimes for experimental synthesis. Data-driven models to guide experimental synthesis. (I) Quantitiative structure-property relation (QSPR) techniques provided a predictive model for the oligomerization thermodynamics and identified pi-peptides with moderate oligomer-ization free energies of ∼(-25) kBT to produced ordered, in-register nanoaggregates. Virtual sceening of 9826 PDI-based pi-peptides informed experimental synthesis, which led to the identification of two distinct regimes of PDI-based electronic coupling. (II) Molecular modeling and data mining identified hydrogen bonding and hydrophobic packing to dictate experimentally observed supramolecular chirality switches and guided experimental control of chirality. (III) A closed loop computational screening platform combining coarse-grained molecular simulation, deep learning, and Bayesian optimization discovered molecules with good in-register pi-core stacking for experimental tests. This work was selected as an ACS Editors' Choice article and featured on the front cover of J. Phys. Chem. B.

BROADER IMPACTS:This project had several notable achievements spanning student training, workforce development and broad dissemination. Graduate mentoring and professional development: This expiring project supported the training of 10 graduate researchers in areas of data science, computational methods, simulation, electrical device characterization and peptide/material synthesis. Students were highly interactive, drove many projects, and prepared publications and presentations. Undergraduate and high school research opportunities: We recruited several undergraduate and high school students, including many from underrepresented groups, for research positions. Many of these students subsequently went on to undergraduate or graduate STEM programs. Broad dissemination and data sharing: Our research findings were the subject of 14 publications and numerous lectures at universities and conferences. Codes and data were made widely available in accordance with FAIR principles for scientific data management and stewardship. A project webpage was established providing information about the team, the research outcomes and the generated data.
